and this is especially true in the field of agriculture or in the food industry.
This is the reason why, in particular, the World Trade Organization was created, on which we agree, and which is trying to establish global rules.

It turns out that it doesn't work quite as we would like, because we are faced with a problem that is as follows: we need to reconcile two things: the necessary free trade that everyone agrees on, but the equally necessary protections.
And protecting national economies or agriculture does not mean protectionism.
To achieve this, the approach we have taken for 60 years since the GATT is an unbalanced path that goes from reducing customs duties with the goal of eliminating them.
it turns out that technically the reduction of customs duties
It's difficult. The proof is in the various mathematical formulas: the South Korean formula, the European formula, or the most well-known one, the Swiss formula.
It doesn't really work because a product is not unitary.
It is composed of many elements with very different rules of origin, and technically reducing tariffs is not as simple as one might think.
We are therefore in a technical deadlock and are trying to find a political way out through negotiations.
Or it turns out that technologically, scientists have invented a new customs technology, the technology of customs duties deductible by the exporter on the economy of the importing state.
in concrete terms, this deductive customs duty is converted into a customs credit equal to the amount of customs duty that the exporter has borne in the importing country
This customs credit has three characteristics: it is refundable, negotiable, and can be increased.
It is refundable at the time when the exporter goes to buy from the importer, he can deduct the customs duty he has borne.
It is negotiable because if the exporting company that has borne the customs duty center has nothing to buy from the importer, it negotiates its customs credit on the stock market or in a bank.
And it is bonifiable if we want to help developing countries by offering an amount of customs credit greater than the amount of customs duties.
Well, with this technique, we create a currency for international trade whose money supply is equal to the amount of existing tariffs.
For example, the European Union would offer 13 billion euros in international currency in the commercial sector.

Commissioner, Minister, over the past three days, the European Development Days have been held, during which the food crisis affecting the poorest countries most severely has been extensively discussed.
The interventions all emphasized the absolute necessity for developing countries to develop their own agriculture by making optimal use of their land and natural resources.

and passing over the lyrical flights of those who yesterday and still today call for reducing state intervention, cutting public spending, liberalizing everything, privatizing, and relegating agriculture to a secondary role, like a
This quasi prehistoric activity, this about-face in favor of massive public investment in agricultural production and food sovereignty, was both ludicrous and scandalous.
The future of agriculture in developing countries is directly related to the debate we are having today.

Unfortunately, I do not feel that this health check of the CAP, initiated before the peak of the hunger riots and the disastrous market disturbances, takes into account the situation of the peasantry in the South and draws all the consequences of the serious ecological, social, economic, and financial risks we are experiencing today.

I therefore deeply regret that the strong relationship between agriculture in the North and the South is so little addressed in both the Commission's proposals and the Parliament's report. The questioning of the billions of euros promised shows just how far we still have to go.

the calculation of the progressive modulation made by the agriculture committee seems fair to me and would allow us to strengthen the development of rural areas and sustainably preserve biodiversity

Mr President, Mr Minister, Commissioner, dear colleagues, our group enthusiastically supports the Small Business Act project that the Commission presented to us last June.

Certainly, from the 2000s onwards, initiatives were taken for SMEs, and I am thinking in particular of the excellent work of our colleague Dominique Glasto on the SME charter, initiatives that were appreciated but deemed insufficient because they too often remained at the state level.
Today, we must go further.
The severe economic crisis that our countries are experiencing, and the consequences of which are particularly worrying for SMEs, invites us to do so, if there were any need.
In this regard, the Small Business Act represents a new, resolutely proactive approach.
In a few weeks, we will examine Mrs Erog's report on the Commission's communication, but today, by tabling this oral question, we wanted to question the Council.
Mr. Minister, we have read with interest the conclusions adopted yesterday by the Competitiveness Council and we would like to know if the European Council on December 11 and 12 will

It will clearly outline its conclusions and will give a strong impetus to ensure that the major guiding principle of "Small First" is quickly transposed into the regulatory framework of the Member States.
We hope that the Council will commit to the principle of the action plan annexed hereto, and that it will result in concrete measures.
In this regard, and in the short time available to me, I will emphasize three areas in which we need binding incentives.
Impact assessments should be systematic, and regular follow-up with monitoring by the European Parliament of the state of implementation of the Small Business Act in the Member States.
Access to the public market.
The code of conduct is not binding. We need to be more imaginative and innovative together and propose concrete, tailored measures that genuinely open up these markets to SMEs.
Finally, access to funding is more essential than ever in the current context.
Your proposals are good, Minister, they must also include support for supply.
There is an emergency.
thank you for assuring us of the Council's willingness.

Mr President, Mr Minister, Mr Commissioner, we all know that SMEs are the backbone of the European Union, as they employ more than 70% of the European Union's workforce and represent 89% of European businesses.

But, as has already been said, these millions of small and medium-sized enterprises are now worried and threatened by the financial crisis because it is eroding purchasing power and household confidence, which is impacting order books.

It is therefore the cash flow of SMEs that is at risk, and it is therefore necessary to ensure that their activities are supported by guaranteeing that banks provide effective access to the financing necessary for the continuity of their operations.
This is the main issue at stake in the conclusions of the Competitiveness Council on December 1, which the Minister mentioned, and in the recovery plan approved by European finance ministers.
Making the needs of SMEs a permanent political priority of the Union is essential, and I would like to commend the Small Business Act for Europe action plan.
It indeed reflects the desire to ensure the effective application of the guiding principle, giving priority to the smallest first, that is to say, to European SMEs.
However, as the Commissioner said, and as we all say, the Council must truly engage with the other institutions.

European. In order for this principle to now be made effective, it is necessary to go beyond the framework of the declaration, it is necessary to move on to implementation in all European policies and programmes.

all on-call time is counted as working time.

It is, in fact, clearly to open up this possibility that the French government has changed its stance on the individual opt-out at the Council.

If we do not want the negative votes in the French, Dutch, and Irish referendums to be followed by many others, calling into question a European Union that gives them the feeling that it does not address their daily problems.

The situation in Gaza is known to everyone.

But we are asking the Security Council to take a stand. We are asking the authorities to take a stand, the European Union to take a stand, while we in Parliament are debating and do not want to take a stand.

I believe that, despite everything, given the urgency of the situation in Gaza, it is of utmost importance that this Parliament takes a stand and clearly states what it wants to do to stop the massacres currently taking place in the Middle East.
I find it unacceptable that this Parliament does not have the courage and clarity to vote on a resolution after our debate.

we want a resolution, we must be aware that we have a political responsibility in the face of what is happening, and this political responsibility cannot simply be a discussion, it must be a resolution that clearly states what we want and what we denounce.
Mr President, Commissioner, more than ever, the proposal for a directive that Parliament is about to vote on evokes in me a very mixed feeling.
It is true that the rapporteur, Mr Klins, has been working tirelessly for years and has negotiated skillfully, particularly during the trilogue.

It is also true that the directive has seen a number of significant advances that contribute to the better functioning of the internal market and the collective management of financial assets, and these have been welcomed as such by the European investment fund industry.

That being said, the debates and discussions in the Council and Parliament were never entirely free, since the outcome was known in advance. For some stakeholders, it was essential to introduce the European passport for management companies at all costs.
In principle, there is nothing to add; the passport defends itself quite well. However, it is necessary to ensure that the introduction of the passport for management companies is appropriate.
It comes with the necessary guarantees, particularly in terms of fund supervision, as it leads to a separation of functions across borders.
Or, I note with regret that the system put in place is not only complex but that it is subject to divergent interpretations.
It is likely to quickly encounter practical difficulties that will harm the European industry, particularly export funds, especially when exporting to third countries.
I have taken due note, my position is in the minority, but I do not feel uncomfortable.
Under normal circumstances, I would have been tempted to say that this practice would allow us to draw definitive conclusions on the matter and thus determine.
Who is right between those who trust in the adaptability of market players and those who adhere to a more cautious approach?
Success is not out of the question, but, on the other hand, nothing guarantees it either.
Or the very recent news, particularly the Madoff scandal and its implications for the collective management of financial assets industry, is not likely to reassure us.
My skepticism is followed by my concern.
The investment fund industry will not be spared by the financial crisis, we can already see that.
Fundamental changes may be necessary, and from this context of crisis

that in these contexts of profound crisis, we operate choices that dilute the responsibilities of the actors or that presuppose perfect cooperation between control authorities can truly seem like an incongruity.
I tell you, as I see it, this directive was also that of a bygone era, from before the crisis.
It is marked by a certain carelessness.
Indeed, the financial system is going through a lasting and fundamental crisis of confidence. Entire sections of its architecture need to be rethought.

We do not forget the primary function of OPCM and the protection of the investor, through risk diversification and the establishment of strict rules. By voting for this text in its current state, without really knowing where we are going, we are doing a bit as if nothing, absolutely nothing, had happened.
This autism is not a good omen, which is why I am abstaining, even though I signed the compromise amendments negotiated with the Council.
In my opinion, the circumstances and the improvements made are of little weight compared to the issues of principle that I have just explained.

Mr President, although the regulation on animal reporting has been in force since January 2007, it appears that the Member States are not systematically complying with the requirement to provide annual reports as requested.
Therefore, a comprehensive analysis remains uncertain since many elements are missing regarding the means put in place to carry out inspections.
As a member of an animal protection association and a member of the animal rights intergroup, this issue is of particular concern to me.
For decades, associations have been fighting desperately to finally establish guidelines in this area in 2007, where member states have shown a certain laxity.
I would even dare say a certain bad faith, because, after all, we know that the implementation of control and inspection is absolutely not insurmountable.
We know the slaughterhouses, we know the farms, we know the routes that cattle take. So where is the problem?

I believe that it is important in our era, where public opinion is increasingly sensitized, and rightly so, by animal welfare, whether in terms of breeding conditions, slaughter, or transportation, that states respect these sentiments.
since I have the floor, I would like to add that, with regard to transport, it would be essential to consider local weather conditions, regardless of the duration of the journey.
Indeed, a several-hour transport journey in the Netherlands in the spring is not comparable to the same journey in the middle of summer in a country like Greece.
Should night transport not be imposed in these latter cases?
Thank you for considering this proposal in the future.

Mr. President, we have indeed all advocated for the closure of Guantanamo and we have all welcomed President Obama's decision to close this prison of shame.
Today, the question of hosting Guantanamo detainees should not be on our minds.
As Europeans, faithful to our values of defending human rights, we must take responsibility, because it is our duty to welcome these former detainees.
And we have read, and I am addressing the Council here, we have read in the press that some Member States were not very enthusiastic about this welcome.
I would really like to appeal to the Council and in particular to the reluctant Member States to agree to receive these female detainees on their territory.
I will tell you, dear colleagues, that the worst thing would be if the goodwill generated by the closure of Guantanamo were to dissipate because we did not respond when Europe was called upon.

This is important because the European animal feed sector is one of the most significant sectors in agriculture, both in terms of production, representing half of agricultural production in the European Union, 120 million tonnes, and in terms of turnover, approximately 50 billion euros.
The European Union has 5 million livestock farmers and 60 million households with pets.

In the past, the European Union has had to deal with a number of health crises, which means that today we must be more vigilant about transparency to meet the expectations of farmers, but also of consumers.

The provisions outlined in this report have the advantage of representing minimal cost to industries and a significant benefit to consumers, who are increasingly attentive to the quality of the products they purchase.
The adoption of this report will help to limit risks by ensuring better product quality, better control, better traceability, and greater information for farmers, and ultimately for consumers.
Today, with the increase in international trade, it is more than imperative to strengthen any prevention mechanism to ensure that the food crises we have experienced in the past do not recur.

This report manages to reconcile the right to information, while strictly defining the nutritional elements that must necessarily appear on labels, and the right to intellectual property, which is so important for preserving the competitiveness of our industries.

I believe that manufacturers should indeed be required to immediately notify the use of any new raw materials in the composition of animal feed in order to ensure transparency and facilitate control by the competent authorities.
Including an emergency procedure that allows for the addition of a new hazardous substance to the list of prohibited materials seems to me to be absolutely essential.

Similarly, giving the breeder the opportunity to consult the competent national authority or the European Commission in case of doubt about an unfair claim allows for better verification of systems to protect the customer while preserving the fairness of commercial transactions.

I therefore wish to lend my full support to this excellent report, because experience shows that regulation on the labelling of animal feed, which I am finishing, Mr President, prioritising quality, transparency, traceability and control, is the best guarantee for preventing new Christianist errors in Europe.

The last element to consider is the expansion of Israeli settlements, which has never stopped since 1967, in the particularly delicate context of the creation of a Palestinian state in East Jordan.
The ball is now in the Israeli camp, but will the hawks on both sides accept this truce of God that both parties are calling for without giving themselves the means to achieve it.
Allow me to add a thought on France's reintegration into NATO's integrated military structure, which will be debated in conjunction with the Vatanen report.
This reintegration will impose severe obligations on France.
Indeed, we are rejoining NATO at a time when the Cold War has been over for eighty years.
Sarkozy seems to have forgotten the fall of the Berlin Wall and Russia's return to the ranks of free nations.
Should the logic of blocs be strengthened at a time when multipolarization and the rise of emerging countries, including in the military sphere, are on the rise?
Furthermore, France's vision of an integrated structure will oblige it to reinforce its contingent in Afghanistan, even though it already has 3,300 men on the ground.
With what budget will it finance itself when its defense budget will fall below 2% of GDP and more than 30 regiments will have to be cut?
Paradoxically, we will increase our budget participation to join NATO and at the same time reduce our military presence in Africa.
European defense, dear to President Sarkozy, will therefore be a pillar of the Atlantic Alliance.
One only had to read the Lisbon Treaty and its additional protocols to be convinced of this.
Whether in terms of foreign policy or common security, the European path is a dead end that will only lead to alignment with the Americans and their allies.
It is this logic of erasure that we reject in the name of sovereignty and national independence, relying in particular on our autonomous nuclear deterrent.
Madam President, I congratulate our three rapporteurs on this quite remarkable synthesis of the current state of our common foreign and security policy.

Mr. Representative, you know better than anyone else that Europe is expected today on the world stage to take the place that its economic and demographic power and the richness of its democratic and humanist values assign to it.

country and in the fight against arms smuggling, which had turned this territory into a launch base for requests of all calibers.

resources, fleet management, compliance with international, regional and bilateral agreements, technical measures and, above all, control - I'll come back to that in a moment.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, I regret that the Council and the Commission have not yet undertaken to define territorial cohesion in concrete terms.

Our Parliament continues to insist that this objective be applicable from the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty and that its contours be specified as soon as possible.

Following the excellent report by Mr Van Nistelroy, I hope that territorial cohesion will become the legal basis, ensuring the harmonious development of all the Union's territories and allowing the best possible use to be made of the specific characteristics of each European region.
It is essential to better coordinate community policies in order to maximize the impact of interventions on the ground.
Territorial cohesion is not exclusively intended for regions suffering from permanent handicaps.
However, it must focus on the polycentric development of the European Union as a whole, taking into account the characteristics of each territory while preserving their diversity.
This new concept seems relevant to me for taking into account the outermost regions in order to ensure their sustainable and balanced growth.

In this regard, I would like to thank the rapporteur for incorporating into these compromise amendments my requests concerning the specific challenges faced by the outermost regions in terms of accessibility and competitiveness, which are essential elements of territorial cohesion.

Madam President, I believe that the issue of food distribution to the most deprived is indeed timely, but I believe that, at its core, the Commission's proposal does not address the problem.
The issue of co-financing concerns me, and I think it is the question of liberalism that has guided our evaluations of the CAP in recent years that should be called into question.
Riots against hunger and sudden fluctuations in food prices are constant indicators of the limits of agricultural market liberalization.
This liberalization has always been at the expense of vulnerable populations, vulnerable producers, and vulnerable territories.

I therefore advocate for politics to regain its rightful place, to take the lead at both the European and global levels, and for the strategic domain of agriculture and human nutrition, both quantitatively and qualitatively, not to be subject to the strict laws of the market.

Mr President, in this period of economic recession, it was important that the European Union continue to demonstrate its solidarity with developing countries.
It is worth recalling that in 2007, the European Community and its Member States together contributed 60% of total development aid, making the European Union the world's largest donor.
The European Development Funds help to combat poverty while promoting economic development and democracy.

I am therefore pleased that for the ACP countries, a budget of twenty-three billion euros has been allocated for the period 2008-2013 as part of the 10th EDF, which is practically double the amount provided for in the 9th EDF.
The audit of the accounts in its report concludes that the accounts of the seventh, eighth and ninth Feds are generally true, legal and regular.
We can only welcome the record levels of contract execution and payments for the implementation of the Fs.
However, I also note that progress must be continued to strengthen the control and monitoring system, as there is still a significant level of errors affecting certain transactions.
Similarly, there is an all too often high risk in terms of budget support, and in my opinion, these risks should be better assessed.
In this regard, I share the view that budget support should only be granted if the recipient country has the capacity to manage the funds in a transparent, responsible, and effective manner.

Among the priorities we need to work on in the future, I would like to mention the integration of aid into the general budget of the community, as this would enhance the effectiveness and transparency of development aid.

For my part, I believe that it is not realistic to admit at this stage that the Copenhagen summit is dead or that it will not result in a conclusive agreement ratified by all parties.
Let us not give in too quickly to pessimism.
I argue that at this stage, we should not lower our ambitions, either in terms of objectives or in terms of deadlines.
We must continue to believe in a comprehensive, ambitious, and binding global political agreement, paving the way for the conclusion of a legal treaty as soon as possible.

Madam President, we all know and have said how important the Copenhagen negotiations are, but while we all hope for an agreement, we cannot accept an agreement at any price.

They will not be satisfied with mere announcements, with unfunded declarations of intent, with non-binding objectives on which it will be possible to wipe one's feet once the media spotlight has faded.

In Copenhagen, the states will have to make a commitment. The European Union, the only continent that has seen its CO2 emissions decrease since 1990, the only continent to plan precise, binding, and ambitious commitments for the future, cannot bear the burden of the effort alone.

By adopting the motion for a resolution tomorrow on the European Union's strategy ahead of the Copenhagen conference, we, European parliamentarians, must demonstrate that our determination is first and foremost total, and that the Conference must result in an agreement that is precise, but above all binding.
Furthermore, the binding nature of this agreement, once reached, must not be called into question or challenged.

We cannot indefinitely postpone decision-making until tomorrow, otherwise it will be too late, which is why the creation of a global environmental organization is necessary today, not only because it is needed but also because it is urgent, as it will be under the auspices of the UN to monitor the implementation of the commitments made in Copenhagen.

The European Union was at the forefront of this platform, not only because of the bold legislation we have in place to limit the impact of our activities on the climate, but also because Europe represents a union of countries that can truly make a difference.
Certainly, the outcome of the Copenhagen conference can only leave a sense of dissatisfaction, but I refuse to speak of failure.
The world has agreed on a 2-degree temperature increase limit, even for the most reluctant countries, such as China.
Brazil has just enacted a law aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions by nearly 39% by the year 2020, in accordance with its commitments.
Many others have also shown great ambition in terms of greenhouse gas reduction targets.
I think of Japan and Norway.
Moreover, it is also important to highlight this very positive point: the consensus reached on the urgency of a mechanism to reduce emissions due to deforestation.

These are SMEs with more than ten employees and a turnover of more than one million euros.
