Admittedly, they may be local and have a limited presence in the Community market, but the need to present accounting rules will not be abolished for them, and that
They will have to deal with accounting rules every time they want to deal with a banking institution, with partners, or negotiate with tax, economic, and social institutions.
At that point, accounting rules will be imposed on them and they may have to pay more than for regular accounting in order to meet criteria that they may not fully understand.
I do not see any progress towards the accounting obligation being imposed outside of all four common to the European Union.
This is not simply a matter of competition. It is quite simply a question of economic integration and Community law and equal treatment for all companies in the European Union.
That being said, of course, simplifying accounting obligations for SMEs is a necessity.
Three initiatives are moving in this direction, whether it is the proposal we are discussing today, or the international IF framework.
LRS, whether it be the revision of the fourth and seventh accounting directives for which the European Commission should soon be making proposals to us.
These proposals were promised to us for 2010, it seems they are being extended, but I do not believe that this extension of the deadline is a sufficient reason for this
to rush and do a half-hearted job, because these three proposals, or if they share the same objective, may not have the same articulation. It seems to me that it would be better, Commissioner.

it is clearer for companies to provide them with a unique and comprehensive response that will enable them to reconcile the goal of simplifying the obligations desired by all and the reality of the lives of small businesses that need them.
The current problem is that the European Commission is dragging its feet in proposing a revision of these directives, and this is detrimental to our thinking.

I therefore call on the European Commission to accelerate the dialogue on the issue of the exemption that is currently dividing both the European institutions and the business community, and to conduct an impact study.

Mr President, Commissioner, and my dear colleagues, as my colleague Elisabeth Morin-Chartier and other colleagues have pointed out, on the 27th and 28th of last February, the violent storm Cynthia hit several regions of France, causing 53 deaths and enormous material damage.
The storm was of rare intensity, causing devastating floods along the French coastline.
After Mainz, Europe is once again affected.
Brittany, the region of my colleague and friend Alain Cadec, was severely affected.
Three French departments have thus been declared to be in a state of natural disaster: Brittany, Poitou-Charente, and the Pays de la Loire.
Faced with these disasters, the European Union must demonstrate its responsiveness and express its solidarity.
It is not only through words and resolutions, but also and above all through financial aid that we can support the victims of these disasters.

I therefore invite my colleague Christophe Bechus to join me in this endeavor, and the European Commission has quickly mobilized the Union's Solidarity Fund to help the affected regions cope with the damage.
This disaster demonstrates the relevance of Michel Barnier's proposal to create a European civilian intervention force.

Europeans must act together because disasters are multiplying and affecting our European territories, particularly our most isolated and vulnerable regions, such as the islands in the Indian Ocean and the Caribbean.

Madam President, I too would like to congratulate our rapporteur Jrg Leichtfried on his report and his spirit of cooperation on this issue, and I particularly support his proposals on the financing of aviation security, since we are talking here about aviation security and not air safety.

Our committee has been fighting for many years to get acceptance for the principle that stricter safety measures must be the responsibility of the Member States, and I fully support our rapporteur on this point.
Indeed, security is not just about travelers, but concerns all citizens, and it is the responsibility of states to take measures to combat terrorism.
It is therefore not justified that air passengers alone should be responsible for financing security measures at airports and on board aircraft.
This is especially true because, in modes of transport such as rail and maritime, states finance security measures, either partially or totally, depending on the case.
I therefore believe that we must remain firm in the face of the Council and defend to the end Amendment 32 of the report adopted by our Committee on Transport.
I had another point to address briefly.

While I support the advancements in non-discrimination and transparency that the text will bring, I do not believe that the purpose of this directive is to establish a single, uniform European system of security charges.
While requiring compliance with common rules, Member States must be allowed to retain their current system of advance fee collection.

Thus, in states like Spain, Italy, or France, fees are voted on by Parliament, and in this case, it should be the authority for appealing against laws that acts as the independent supervisory authority.
This is the purpose of Amendment 40, which I hope many of you will support when we vote on it.
Mr President, Commissioner, the report I am presenting to Parliament attempts to explain that, in the fight against global warming, agriculture has a place and a role to play.
Nature reminds us this week that volcanoes, in particular, can have a major impact on human activities and on the climate.
But this still requires that people, and Europe in particular, take responsibility for combating what is called global warming.
My report attempts to demonstrate that agriculture can simultaneously continue to reduce its carbon emissions, decrease its fossil fuel consumption, and, above all, achieve something else.
On the side, they actively participate in carbon fixation to globally combat fewer carbon emissions and more and more carbon fixed and sequestered.
This report attempts to demonstrate that in agriculture, we should move away from a compartmentalized approach, where a new directive is introduced every time a problem arises.
on soil, on water, on pesticides, who knows what else, and to try to address the agricultural issue with the ambition to deal with it in a comprehensive, systemic way, and
In this approach, we should be able to find ways to ensure that agriculture, as I mentioned earlier, not only reduces its energy consumption but also actively participates in carbon sequestration.
This is particularly the role related to photosynthesis, biomass, and above all, what I hold dear, also related to the soil, the capacity of European soils to sequester organic carbon.

I believe that this approach, which I am opening up in this report and which I hope will be followed during the vote that will take place in plenary in Brussels, must enable European agriculture to enter a phase of sustainability, ensuring

ecological transition to an agriculture that would put it ahead of a number of other continents or other forms of agriculture, in order to ensure that it is capable of being economically efficient, ecologically efficient, and I also believe, from that point on, socially efficient.

This report deals with a specific issue: the fight against global warming and agriculture, but it aims, I hope in any case, to open up other perspectives to fuel, in particular, the debate that will take place on the future of agricultural policy after 2013.
I am addressing the Commission, I will address and I have often addressed the agricultural committee, I will also address the various ministers when I have the opportunity.
I think we need to take a turn.
This 2013 pact must be ambitious.
It must be based on objectives that enable citizens to understand why we need a common agricultural policy.
We need a common agricultural policy because the Europe of agriculture must ensure both food security and commit to the path of sustainability.
This is, in any case, what I propose in this report and this is what I hope Parliament will follow, by a large majority.

Mr President, I would first like to emphasise that the precautionary principle implemented by most European governments by closing their airspace in a targeted and temporary manner was a wise and prudent decision.

The safety of our fellow citizens must take precedence over all other considerations, and under these circumstances, the attitude of certain airlines demanding the immediate and total reopening of airspace after just one or two test flights appears to be, at the very least, indecent.

I believe it was Mr. Heain earlier who spoke about the complementarity of transport modes, particularly with trains, and I will take this opportunity to express how much I regret the air travel paralysis.
This has been exacerbated in some countries, such as France, by the disruption of rail transport due to strikes in these irresponsible and incomprehensible circumstances.
To return to our topic, I would like to commend the Commission's decision to authorize the granting of public aid to airlines affected by the ongoing disruptions.
It is a common-sense decision in a context already marked by crisis, but its aid must be exceptional in nature.

In this regard, I hope that among the criteria chosen for their award will be the exemplary conduct demonstrated by the companies in compensating their customers who were victims of flight cancellations.
Indeed, it is not acceptable that certain companies abuse the force majeure clause in order to escape their obligation to compensate passengers under Regulation 261/2004.
Travelers are victims of the current situation and, if no alternative solution is offered to them, they should not, in addition, bear the financial cost.
In addition, travel agencies are exempt from the obligation to reimburse travelers for unused flights.
And that is not normal either.

Companies, including travel agencies, have insurance that covers them in exceptional cases, such as the one we have been experiencing for the past few days, and therefore it is necessary to ensure that travelers are properly compensated for flights that have been canceled.
Mr President, paddling, chaos, paralysis, cacophony, catastrophes, disasters, the monuments believe in the press to evoke the closure of European airspace and its consequences.
I will not dwell on what has already been said, particularly regarding the extent of the colossal, abyssal financial impact of this crisis, whether in direct or indirect terms.

And while I welcome the possibility of considering exceptional public aid for the aviation sector, which has been severely tested since September 11, 2001, I remain perplexed about the European management of events.

knowing that 715 European passengers have been affected, many of whom are still stranded all over the world. Knowing that the economic losses are exponential with the passage of time, how can we explain that it took?
It's not one, two, three or four, but five days for European transport ministers to meet by teleconference to coordinate their actions and decide on the creation of differentiated traffic zones.
Secondly, no one disputes the need to apply the precautionary principle as a matter of absolute priority, but today, as traffic is gradually being reauthorized in areas
With the flight secured, the weather unchanged, and the volcano still active, one has to wonder what additional safety guarantees for passengers we could not have provided more quickly.

Third, a dynamic action model has been developed, which evolves according to the mete where the volcano's activity can change, and which will continue to conduct updated safety assessments of the corridors.
Should these test flights be carried out by civil aviation and airlines?

Finally, if this continues, worsens, or recurs (which is likely), the management model put in place will need to provide for greater coordination among member states and special operational procedures based on real data, as well as better

coordination of other means of transport in exceptional circumstances, but we must also take into account the necessary coordination of assistance for the repatriation of the tens of thousands of stranded passengers who also have a right to information and assistance.
Or, up to now, only isolated and national initiatives have been taken. Madame Delvo, who has the floor?

Thank you, Madam President. I would like to join other speakers in expressing my gratitude to our colleague Mendes Di Vigo, who has done remarkable work under sometimes passionate and always exciting conditions.
the debates within the Committee on Conventional Affairs lasted a long time, they were equal to the challenge and equal to the intensity of the interest that is obviously being shown
European parliamentarians quite legitimately focus on the major issue that concerns them most: the composition of our assembly and the procedures for designating the members of our assembly.
once again, the rapporteur has managed to bring together sometimes differing opinions and contributions and synthesize them, I would say, in an extremely balanced text, the opinions and views
I wanted to thank him for that

I believe that the recommendations of these two reports, both the one concerning the convening of the IGC and the one concerning the transitional measures for the composition of our assembly, are imbued with realism, pragmatism, and efficiency.
I know, I believe that, overall, on other subjects as well, fellow citizens expect something from Europe.
Mr President, Mr Dali, Commissioner, this draft report, as just presented by Mr Pterlet, takes up the lines with a great deal of force.
Director of Communication of the European Commission and is also inspired by the European Parliament's resolution of 10 April 2008 on the fight against cancer in our European Union.

Allow me to support the objectives of the European partnership envisaged by the European Commission to combat cancer more effectively, whether it is the importance of prevention and early detection, the development of a new cancer prevention model, and above all, the reduction of inequalities within the Member States.
I share the concerns and worries expressed in the European Commission's communication and the draft report.
I would like to commend the work done by Mr. Pterli, the rapporteur, in drafting this report and the compromise proposals put forward to incorporate the various amendments.

As the shadow rapporteur for the Socialist and Democrat group, I wanted, among other things, to emphasize the following issues: first, the increase in annual cancer-related deaths caused by exposure to carcinogens in the workplace, but also the importance of better access.

information on medicines for cancer patients, but also the implementation of the REACH regulation and the regular updating of substances of very high concern, which includes carcinogenic substances, support for initiatives to prevent the import of goods

containing chemical substances, and to strengthen control of the presence of chemical substances within the European Union, and finally, the development of guidelines for a common definition of disability that could include people suffering from chronic illnesses or cancer.
These are the questions we have been considering while providing our support for this draft report.
Madam President, the oil rig leak in the Gulf of Mexico is a true ecological and economic disaster.
It would appear that irregularities have been found in the granting of forest permits by the US Department of the Interior.
This would be an unforgivable oversight, the consequences of which are incalculable and do not concern only the United States of America.

When one considers that hundreds of offshore drilling permits are granted by states around the world, if these permits were granted with the same laxity, it would pose a truly serious problem for the entire world.
elected from outermost European regions and OCTs composed entirely or almost entirely of islands, nearly 130
distributed across three continents, I must express here my deep concern for our islands regarding offshore oil exploration projects.
This is why it is imperative that the European Union, which must set an example, reviews the safety and prevention measures on its own offshore oil platforms with the utmost rigor.
Moreover, accidental or operational oil spills at sea, not necessarily due to Europe, are estimated at several tens of thousands of tons each year.

Would it not be appropriate for the European Union to take initiatives so that offshore platforms now fall under the jurisdiction of an undisputed international scientific authority, which should be established in the form of an international body?

After Copenhagen and in preparation for Cancun, the European Union would be honoured to initiate a genuine global governance framework for the research, protection and exploitation of deep-sea resources.
The continuity of the Barcelona Process, the Union for the Mediterranean, is an opportunity for the development of our relations with the countries of the East and South of the Mediterranean basin.
And as the excellent report by Vincent Payillon points out, we cannot overlook either the potential of this region or the dangers it poses.
However, having the lucidity to recognize this, since the bombing of Gaza and the continued colonization of Palestinian territories, the Union for the Mediterranean is at an impasse.
The political aspect is blocked.
We are not even certain that the summit scheduled for next June in Barcelona will actually take place.
I would not be surprised if we learned in the coming hours or days that he is on a synodical day.
We must not, however, give up, but the European Union must take greater responsibility in the search for a political solution.
We cannot leave the United States with a monopoly on the political management of the crisis in this region, which is our own, by merely contributing to its development.
The development and stability of the Mediterranean are crucial for our security and growth, and for this reason, the Union for the Mediterranean remains the best instrument at our disposal.
Mr. President, Commissioner, this is an extremely important issue concerning consumer protection.
A recent survey indicates that the food safety situation has deteriorated over the past ten years in the eyes of Europeans, and one in three consumers remains wary of product quality.
Updating, simplifying, and clarifying the labeling of food products in the European Union is a requirement for better consumer protection.
Allow me to address two points.
Regarding the color code, we are in favor of this color code if it is accompanied by a reference to the nutritional values expressed as a percentage.
And then I am opposed to mandatory nutritional labeling for wines and spirits.
We want a specific regulation for wine and spirits to be developed in the next three years, rather than the five years proposed by the European Commission.
That is what I wished to indicate, Mr. President, Commissioner.
Mr President, Madam High Representative, this attack on a civilian ship by Israeli commandos obviously requires an impartial and credible investigation.
But what credibility could we grant to a commission that would be both judge and party?
This attack occurred in international waters, and therefore concerns the international community, and is of particular interest to Europe, which borders the Mediterranean.
Europe should make its voice heard more and become more involved in the search for a political solution based on two states, each with Jerusalem as its capital.

Europe is making considerable financial efforts to contribute to the development of Palestinian territories, but unfortunately, it is too absent from the political process that should lead to the creation of this Palestinian state.
The financial and budgetary goodwill we are showing is not enough.
We must also express a political will and take the necessary steps to make ourselves heard.
Brutal attack on Mavi Marmara by Israeli army provokes emotions and condemnation
There was an outpouring of emotion for the nine civilian victims of the attack, and condemnation because this reasoning in international waters constitutes a violation of international law.

In doing so, the government of Israel is penalizing its people because, in the end, we see, with the strengthening of the extremes, the ultimate goal of security in the region moving a little further away.
Yes, more than ever, the government of Israel must abandon the policy of force.
However, I would like to point out that the extensive media coverage of the Mavi Marmara flotilla, orchestrated from Turkey, casts doubt on the exclusively humanitarian purpose of this operation.
An investigation seems essential to shed light on the assault, as well as on the preparations that preceded this expedition.
I hope that the government of Israel will agree that this investigation includes substantial international participation in order to finally find the paths of justice in this region.
Madam President, Madam High Representative, I welcome the new momentum generated by the launch of the Partnership for Modernization and its pragmatism.
This new partnership, if it comes to fruition, would at least have the merit of highlighting just how indispensable Russia is as a geopolitical partner for the European Union.
I also welcome the positive statements on cooperation with Russia in crisis management.
A few remarks, however.

While the Union's demands are always emphasized, the interests or positions of its partner seem systematically undervalued or disregarded, whether it is in the field of energy or in the way it can analyze the Eastern partnership and the Atlanticist aspirations of its closest neighbors.
I also note that the firmness displayed by most Member States and the Union in their discourse, the virulence of their condemnations of human rights violations, seems reserved exclusively for Russia.

The language is more police-like, diplomacy is more subdued, as if we are talking about China, for example, and its systematic violations of the rule of law. What about the Laogai camps, that global factory in the face of European minimum social requirements, when our French or European workers are unemployed?

Let me remind you of the adage by d'Agusta, "Father Augusta, to the heights by narrow roads," for that is how I view the efforts of today's Russia, freed from the criminal poison of Marxism that, for so many decades, bled and imprisoned this country.
The current Russian Federation has managed to lift the spirits of an entire nation, despite the significant challenges and setbacks it still faces.

So a little modesty, gentlemen Europeanists, especially when the European superstate fails to achieve any of its lofty goals despite increasingly costly resources and the progressive domination of the Western European and Central and Eastern European states.
I cannot help but point out that this assembly showed more indulgence towards the more communist Soviet Union than towards Russia.

Moreover, it is often the same people who, yesterday, were advocating for the unilateral disarmament of the West and for participation in Mr. Gorbachev's common home, who today express the most virtuous indignation and the greatest shame regarding the partnership with the Russian Union.

In this regard, I must inform you, if you are not already aware, of new historical phases that will emerge as a result of the gradual translation of the secret Soviet archives, which the resourceful M. Pavel Stroilov has managed to obtain. These archives have already provided, and will continue to provide, a wealth of information.

There are unpleasant surprises in the conventional wisdom about the reality of the end of the Cold War, who M. Gorbatov really was, and the perfidy of today's Euro-enthusiastic powers who were then eager to make certain Soviet projects possible.
At the risk of repeating myself, Russia is an essential and strategic partner for European states, and our relations must be strengthened for the benefit of all parties.

This country is much closer to us in terms of culture, civilization, history, geography, mutual interests, and common risks than some of the states that you are preparing to admit to the European Union.
President of the Council, it is often said that necessity makes law.
Faced with the crisis, one thing is clear: a necessity has become undeniable, that of innovating, of being creative.

In this regard, I welcome the step taken by the Council  a step that I hope will eventually be a giant leap, leading us towards true economic governance, because let us not be mistaken, the mere coordination of economic policies will remain insufficient.
May we achieve a true fiscal federation, not forced by circumstances, but because we ourselves have decided it.
let's return to the council's decision, which I am still pleased about.
Strengthening the preventive arm of the Stability and Growth Pact is a good thing, but there can be no real budgetary discipline without sanctions for those who violate it.
They have been strengthened, but not yet specified, which is a shame.

Otherwise, I will express my satisfaction, among other things, regarding the decisions made, such as the famous competitiveness evaluation dashboard, because this is precisely what it is about: to reconnect with competitiveness and sustainable growth for all.
Once again, the project of introducing a bank tax, the acceptance of a tax on financial transactions, and the acceleration of financial regulation reform.
Mr President of the Council, all these decisions and guidelines seemed a few months, or even a few weeks ago, unrealistic, illusory, or even truly hypothetical.
You are right, it is true, it is a profound cultural change on the scale of European small-scale policy.
But having said that, it is now imperative that in October, the states implement these guidelines in a very concrete manner.

It will now depend on the Council whether the step taken is a historic giant leap or simply a pious hope, something we will all bitterly regret and, in particular, a majority, the citizens who will have to endure it on a daily basis.

Mr President, we have already discussed this at the Conference of Presidents. Many groups are divided on this report and it is clear that Parliament, all the groups, still need to discuss it because there are problems, contradictory points that the groups have not been able to resolve.
That is why we are asking to postpone the debate and the vote on the Gallop report, that is to say until September 2, when the Conference of Presidents will take place.
So it's a very simple thing.
Since the fruit is not ripe, let's give it the summer to ripen and discuss it in September.

Madam President, I must admit that I find it difficult to keep up with my colleagues who so love to flex their muscles and claim a monopoly on our legitimacy vis--vis the other institutions of the Union.
Unfortunately, their posture is often derisory.
But when the members of this house, through hard work and conviction, assert a reasoned position when
We are defending what appears to be a general European interest in the face of rigid states; the situation is changing completely.
In this debate on European supervision, Parliament has played this role.
Regarding the European Systemic Risk Board, for which I am my group's shadow rapporteur, I have defended, like the rapporteur, Mrs Goulard, an ambitious approach.
I have designed mechanisms to ensure a certain level of efficiency and I have emphasized the preeminent role of the European Central Bank.
Why?
Because the European Central Bank is indeed the only Community institution in this context and because it has demonstrated its seriousness.
Out of Christian charity, I will withhold the names of all the institutions and all those great figures who suddenly disappeared during the storm.
We can consider ourselves fortunate to have had at least one captain on board at the height of the crisis.
I would therefore be reassured to see macro-prudential supervision backed by a strong Community institution tomorrow, while micro-prudential supervision will inevitably remain fragmented.
In some troubled times, the European Systemic Risk Board must get to work as quickly as possible.
The future will show whether adjustments will be necessary, but it is essential to start on a sound basis because systemic risks affect the entire banking sector, both in Europe and globally.
Mr President, the final agreement reached on the recast of the industrial emissions directives is more than acceptable and I welcome the compromise work that has been done.
This final package incorporates the key points I advocated for with several of my colleagues on the Environment Committee, aiming to make this text an ambitious yet realistic piece of legislation.
First, maintaining a certain flexibility for companies and competent authorities in granting exemptions.
Next, I would like to commend the new version of the OSN, which has been so controversial and, now limited to certain sectors, seems much more feasible.

It is also important to note that the agreement reached allows for better alignment with the ETS directive and definitively removes from the text of the new directive the irrelevant idea of creating a market for SO2 and NOX quotas.
A few caveats not to be forgotten, however, and more particularly the provisions concerning the ground.
Since the SOL directive is still pending, this important issue will unfortunately only be addressed by the Member States that have their own legislation.
Tomorrow, Parliament must adopt the elements of the agreement reached at the end of the trilogues.

A tremendous amount of work has been done from all sides to avoid sending this text back to conciliation, a text that, I must remind you, is of crucial importance both for the industry and for European environmental policy.
Madam President, each day brings new information that shows us the extent of the ecological disaster caused in the Gulf of Mexico by the rupture of the offshore platform.
But let's not forget that other disasters of this kind are taking place elsewhere.
I am thinking in particular about what is happening today and has been happening for a long time in Nigeria.
That is why, in addition to the moratorium on new drilling, I believe there is a need to promote stricter rules for the management of platforms, not only European rules, but also international rules.
As for the European Union, I believe it is necessary for it to equip itself preventively to combat this disaster, and I believe it is obvious.
and that all of this, as Mrs. Damanki said, argues for a firm and decisive choice in favor of clean and renewable energy.
The European Union should set an example in this regard.

Mr President, Commissioner, reopening negotiations with Mercosur at a time when the European Union is preparing to redefine its agricultural policy reveals a dangerous lack of coherence on the part of the Commission.
Europe already imports 500 thousand tons of beef.
A new opening of our market will be made at the expense of farmers from disadvantaged areas in Europe, without any guarantee that health and social standards will be respected.
We cannot accept it.
Europe buys thirty-eight million tons of soybeans and cattle feed.
These imports from Brazil and Argentina monopolize more than nineteen million hectares.
They are concentrated in the hands of three companies: Cargill, ADM, and Bonsch.
Between 2001 and 2004, soy destroyed more than 1.2 million hectares of tropical and equatorial forests.
This was one of the primary causes of the increase in greenhouse gas emissions and the disappearance of biodiversity.
The European Parliament has decided to produce a report on the reconquest of autonomy in plant proteins for cattle feed.
Environmentally friendly agriculture and the fight against climate change dictate this choice.
These efforts will be reduced to nothing by this draft bilateral agreement.
Once again, the European Commission is selling out its agriculture and its farmers in order to obtain random counter-services for service companies.
These concessions will not serve the farming families of Mercosur, but the interests of agro-industrial groups.
To be convinced of this, one need only read the report of the Tyson group, an American company and a heavyweight in the international meat market.
which announced that it had invested in Brazil to, and I quote, use this country as an export platform for Europe, according to its report.
other companies, such as the company Doux, had already anticipated this approach by acquiring the Brazilian group Franco Soulul in 1998
Many poultry farmers, particularly in Brittany, had suffered as a result of this operation.
Europe, without wanting to pursue its policy of relocation by amplifying its attacks.
against the peasants. we must stop
Mr President, many colleagues are concerned about the consequences for European agriculture that could result from the reopening of negotiations on an association agreement with Mercosur.
My group and I share these concerns.

There is cause for concern, in fact, and as a Member of Parliament for an outermost region, I have experience with banana agreements. Therefore, there is cause for concern that an agreement with Mercosur could impose a difficult cost on many European agricultural sectors.
This is why an impact study is absolutely necessary.
There is also a concern that this agreement will further shift Mercosur agriculture towards a productivist model, to the detriment of small farms that exist in these countries.

A balance must be found so that this agreement does not transform the Latin American and European continents into superpowers anchored essentially in the dogma of mercantilism. Mr. President, thank you.
Mr President, I would simply like to say that perhaps we have not done our agenda very well today.
If we allow free trade agreements to bring products into Europe that do not respect our social or environmental standards, the CAP reform will be for nothing.
To put it very clearly, we cannot continue to live in hypocrisy, where on the one hand we impose environmental constraints, health traceability, and safety measures.
To our farmers, on the grounds that consumers must be protected, and on the other hand, to allow products that can freely enter our continent without restrictions.
The question that underlies the negotiations with Mercosur is indeed this one.

the way things were initiated, despite what we are being told about the fact that Parliament was very well informed that things were carried out with the utmost transparency and clarity, does not lead us to have a positive view of a negotiation that is taking place, while at the same time, negotiations are continuing at the WTO.
In the name of consistency in defending consumers and defending our farmers, I do not believe we should continue down this path.

Madam President, I would also like to commend the work done by the rapporteur, Jos Boveis, and the Commissioner, as well as the speech by Mr Des, who spoke before me about the objectives of this report.

I think it is very important that we keep in mind that in the debate we are having, we are dealing with a problem related to price volatility in agriculture and, above all, to the fact that when prices
When prices increase, they are very quickly passed on to the distribution level, but when prices decrease at the production level, there are no repercussions for consumers.
There is indeed a problem with the organization of the sector, there is indeed a problem with the distribution of what is called added value within the sector.
I believe that Jos Boveis' report offers several perspectives that need to be highlighted, and I am really addressing the Commission to try to get out of this fundamentally negative spiral.
The first, of course, is the organization of the sector and the balance of power within the sector. Therefore,
What are the proposals we are making to enable producers to come together, organize, and have more influence within the sector in order to negotiate?
That is the question you raised, Commissioner, about inter-branch organizations, but it is also a question about the contractual framework that will be put in place.
I argue in the report that this contractual basis is a European framework.
We cannot let each country deal with this problem on its own.
There needs to be a European framework.
It must be flexible, but it must exist.
It is a proposal, an inseparable line of thought for me.
I am, of course, referring to the issue of price transparency.
And in this regard, I am in favor of setting up this observatory, which is absolutely necessary so that we can inform consumers about price trends.
here I am, I support the proposals that are being made and I hope, as Mr. Des said, that there will be a majority to pursue them

Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I wanted to take this opportunity today to welcome this debate, which once again highlights the need for the Union to appreciate and enhance its regional diversity.
In these times of negotiation for the new 2014 framework programmes, it did not seem to me to be necessary to emphasize the adjustments that specific regions should benefit from.
Issues of territorial continuity and cohesion must be at the heart of our concerns.
But the development of mountainous, island or sparsely populated areas requires more than a set of derogating measures.
We need a horizontal approach.
We must establish instruments capable of making all areas of community action coexist in synergy in order to enhance their added value.
Moreover, as a representative of the outermost regions, I am eagerly awaiting the new EU strategy for the ORs that the Commission services promised us for early 2011.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, first of all, I agree with my colleague's position on the Council's absence from this Parliament meeting.
I find this a bit flippant on the part of the Council, I must say that too.
As the next summit approaches on October 6, China and the European Union must absolutely and resolutely try to move forward together on the issue of climate change.
Last year at this time, we were already busy in this very chamber, urging Europe to do everything possible to reach an ambitious and binding agreement in Copenhagen.
We have seen that the result did not live up to our hopes and ambitions.
So the concerns a year later are the same, if not even much more acute.

In order to be able to compel or convince our partners today, we must demonstrate that our determination is absolutely intact, show, for example, that we are providing ourselves with the means to honor our commitments to the countries of the South.
For this reason, the implementation of innovative financing mechanisms, and I heard President Sarkozy's speech at the UN yesterday, becomes a necessary necessity.
For example, the introduction of a carbon tax at our borders is not to be ruled out.

It would act as an incentive mechanism for countries that do not go far enough in their climate commitments, and much more than a threat in the end, and a means of protecting our jobs and businesses, especially to better address the pre-crisis situation.

Madam President, for me, the need to revalue family leave is not approved. Raising the minimum threshold for maternity leave is a step forward and a benefit, and one should not be entirely demagogic in comparing the economic impact to the qualitative benefits that are difficult to quantify.

But the problem is essentially twofold: first, the economic context, which is true, but not sufficient to leave millions of families stranded for decades. Second, the legal shortcomings of the report, as the text includes several types of family leave whose legal bases are not compatible.
Let's take the adoption leave that is mentioned in the text in the same way as maternity and paternity leave.
I personally appreciate, as an adoptive mother and for all those I represent, the desire to grant equivalent rights to those of biological mayors.
I am actually the extra little package that Mrs. Morin added to the EtrLA report.

If the goal is to promote the health and rights of all women in the workforce, then adoptive women, who have become mothers just like anyone else, are entitled to the same rights and protections at work.
They are mothers like any other, fully entitled to be so, whether they adopt a child who is more or less than twelve months old; by the way, no discrimination, please, as it is mentioned in the text.
Regarding adoption, therefore, I regret that the text was not thoroughly enough examined.
It was not even informed by the Rambo impact study.
This is all rather poorly executed, which is clearly a weak point.

Nevertheless, despite these reservations, I will support Mrs. Estrella's report because, beyond economic considerations, there are men and women who must not only better assume their role as parents in a society that is

Increasingly resigned in the face of the education of these young people, but also because it is our duty to ensure that no one has to choose between sacrificing their children for their work or sacrificing their work for their children.
Finally, we do not sit on the Council but in Parliament. If we directly elected representatives are not ambitious, tell me who will be.
Madam President, Commissioner, Mr President of the Council, I would like to speak and not revisit the debate as it has unfolded so far.

We discussed a 2011 budget with the constraints we are aware of, namely those of a deep crisis that Europe is going through, with public deficits at the national level, which can lead to two hypotheses.
These public deficits at the national level constrain the European deficit, or these deficits at the national level must give a new direction and a new impetus at the European level.
That is the question.
I ask you, Commissioner, especially when discussing a budget review, when we start talking about the budget outlook for the period after 2013, not to
remain totally absorbed by the context of the crisis, unless I tell myself and all the citizens of Europe that, indeed, Europe will remain in crisis for a long time.
Our whole problem is indeed to manage the crisis and reduce our deficits and debt, but it is also to prepare for the exit from the crisis.
And this is where the budgetary question arises.

We will only be able to emerge from the crisis, as Joseph Dale pointed out right at the start, if the European budget, because it is European, is capable of giving us the means to regain what we lack today: growth, job creation, innovation, and research.

This is the issue at stake, and it is in this context that we must discuss the budget, rather than constantly integrating the issue of the crisis and the issue of deficits, as we all too often do. In this regard, the Council is excellent.

I noted that in Deauville, Angela Merkel and Nicolas Sarkozy even preemptively announced a reform of the treaties, without even having discussed it with Mr. Van Rompuy at all, in order to sanction all the states that would not respect budgetary discipline tomorrow.

This is where we stand with the Council today, while Parliament is asking for one thing, particularly from the Commission, which is to try to pull the European project forward, and this is happening through the budget.
So you have noted a number of things on which we fully agree.
More fixation is needed.
Obviously, we need to find a way to collectively develop a much more flexible budget capacity, because these are necessities and Europe's responsiveness is at stake.
It is also, of course, a matter of setting priorities and organizing the efficiency of the European budget.
We will all agree on this, all agree, it is a necessity.
But what we need to be clear about, Commissioner, is that we need a timetable, that we need to set objectives together. This cannot remain just words, just commitments, just...

These texts are, incidentally, very interesting and I agree with them practically 100%. But now, we need to get down to specifics, particularly on an essential issue that we keep circling around: own resources.

How do we ensure that we have our own resources for Europe tomorrow, not just for Europe, but for all European citizens, and how can we find a way to regain growth together, a path that is even stronger for Europe?
It is up to you, sir.
Mr President, I would like to focus my remarks on the preparation for the next G20 summits.

Everything has been said by the previous speakers about European economic governance, about the need to strengthen European economic governance, to strengthen the Stability and Growth Pact and to better involve the European Parliament and, of course, the national parliaments in the process.
I would like to briefly mention two challenges that our nations and the G20 members face, and which, in my opinion, must be addressed in the context of the upcoming G20 meetings.
The challenge of the currency war is that of the volatility of raw material prices.
I believe that, on these two issues which are real threats to global growth and which cause very significant imbalances on our planet, the Union must

The European Union is managing to organise itself, to establish common positions, and to give itself the means to speak with a single voice at the upcoming G20 summits in Seoul, as well as those that will follow, and more broadly, on the world stage. Thank you.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by congratulating our colleague Diogo Feio on the quality of the report and on the ambitious proposals it contains.
This also demonstrates that the European Parliament is taking its rightful place in a debate that is crucial for the future of Europe, and we can only welcome this.
Moreover, the Greek crisis has revealed the dysfunctions that undermine the economic governance of the European Union.
I take note of Mr Feio's proposal to establish a permanent mechanism for financial stability.
We must also address the problem at its root.
To achieve this, I believe that the solution also lies in strengthening the Stability and Growth Pact, particularly the sanctions.
This is essential if we want a sustainable improvement in the budgetary situation of the states, which is not always popular.
It's restrictive, but we have no choice.

Mr President, I believe that the report clearly demonstrates the challenges posed by the marine environment in terms of fishing, aquaculture, transport, tourism, energy, mineral and biological wealth, and research, combined with climate change.
This is a considerable development potential that must be secured, protected, and sustainably enhanced, because the future of humanity depends on it.
The report also rightly notes that the European Union is the world's leading maritime power and that these outermost regions offer it the largest exclusive economic zone in the world.
In view of this situation, it is therefore up to the European Union to implement an ambitious policy, a major maritime policy.
If it is not the world's leading maritime power that does it, who will do it instead?
But France must note that the resolution does not go very far down this path.
One cannot claim to occupy a leadership position in global politics with 50 million euros.
Finally, while the outermost regions have a recognized strategic position, as they are present in all oceans, it would be
It was wise to give them a major role in a major ocean strategy, which unfortunately was not included in the report and I regret that. Thank you, Mr. President.
Commissioner, I would like to revisit the anti-counterfeiting agreement currently being negotiated, particularly with the United States.
This agreement also raises questions in the United States, particularly among officials at the US Patent Office.
in addition, seventy-five American law professors have just sent a letter to President Obama.
He believes that ACTA, this simple executive agreement, would be contrary to the American Constitution.
while the European Parliament is preparing, as you know, to adopt a resolution on the ACTA agreement, which still raises major concerns and is far from being unanimously supported
I believe it would be useful for our fellow citizens to receive a very clear response from our American counterparts. On two points: Can ACTA be ratified by the United States?
In their eyes, is ACTA a binding or voluntary agreement?
Indeed, an anti-counterfeiting agreement from which China, India, and Brazil are already absent, and which would not be implemented by the United States, greatly loses its credibility.
thank you

Mr President, throughout this difficult birth of the Alternative Investment Fund Directive, I have consistently advocated for the principle of equal treatment between fund managers, whether they are from the European Union or not.
This principle sounds like an obvious truth, but its obviousness has encountered countless difficulties.
The result presented to us today is satisfactory.
I thank the negotiators and especially our rapporteur, Mr Gass, who, after this particularly painful birth, deserves a substantial maternity leave.
I would particularly like to emphasize that the issue of how to treat third countries must still be considered in two ways, whether one is inside or outside the European Union.
Thanks in particular to the European Parliament, all funds that will be sold in the European Union will indeed be subject to comparable regulation.
One can therefore more or less speak of a Love playing field.
However, during the transitional period, non-EU entities will benefit from the national investment regime, while EU funds and managers will be subject to the directive, which is generally stricter.
The situation is different in markets outside the European Union. There, European funds and their managers are subject to the directive, which is not the case for third-country funds.
It would then be much more difficult to sell European products in the rest of the world, as they would be less flexible and more cult-like.
We must be aware of this disadvantage, even if it was partly inevitable.

As for the custodians, knowing that we will also make the exercise more demanding, particularly due to the new responsibilities they will have to assume, the increase in costs should lead to substantial changes in the profession.

Mr. President, I am not saying this to show my opposition, but to indicate that this new regulation is not trivial; its implementation, which is necessary, will also involve difficulties that we must be aware of.

Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, especially at the beginning of the 21st century, patients need appropriate information in order to be fully involved in their care pathway, to know where to seek care, to decide on the best treatment in agreement with health professionals, and to follow the prescribed treatment to the letter.
Today, patients demand independent, comparative information tailored to their individual needs.
Unfortunately, the proposals for revising the directive submitted by the European Commission did not adequately address the needs expressed by European citizens.
These proposals opened the door to direct promotion by pharmaceutical companies, which we see as nonsensical in terms of responding to the actual needs of patients.
This operation is of no interest to either the citizens or the Member States.
On the contrary, it meant more bureaucracy, increased expenses, and putting patients at risk.
It is for these reasons that we initially submitted a draft proposal of these texts, thereby asking the Commission to revise its draft.
This approach, also adopted by my colleague Carl Schulter from the Green group, enabled our rapporteur, Mr Fechner, whom I commend, to make significant revisions to the Commission's proposals.

In parallel, we had tabled around sixty amendments aimed at further protecting the health of our citizens and facilitating patients' access to independent, comparative information tailored to each individual's needs.

The adoption of these amendments in the Environment Committee has placed greater emphasis on patients' rights to information, rather than making the provision of information an option for the pharmaceutical industry.

In light of the compromise amendments obtained, we have decided to withdraw our position of rejection of the texts, as the substance of the text has evolved in a positive direction over the past few months.
The draft report, as amended, has managed to counterbalance the European Commission's initial proposals.

However, we will continue to refuse to allow healthcare professionals to be used as tools to distribute their patients, brochures, and information provided by pharmaceutical companies without any oversight from health authorities.
Similarly, we will oppose the authorization of industrial campaigns, particularly for information on vaccination.
Information cannot come freely from pharmaceutical companies.

Experience shows that we must be very vigilant and, moreover, what happened with the mediator drugs demonstrates just how vigilant we need to be and how we must ensure that this balance is maintained, as we have sought to do with this draft report.
Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, unity and realism will be demonstrated, at least I hope so, during tomorrow's vote on our resolution on this 16th Conference of the Parties on climate change.

I hope that our commissioner in charge will be able to achieve the pragmatic objectives that we will need to reach collectively, but also defend the essential conditions set by Europe that are associated with them.
In these negotiations, we must also not lose sight of the legitimate expectations of fairness of our fellow citizens and our industries.
It is the world that must combat climate change, not Europe alone.
Thus, recognizing the importance of intellectual property that is inadequately protected will be essential.

Green technologies should benefit the greatest number of people, but we must not, for all that, squander our present and future knowledge, including that for this indispensable fight against climate change.

Similarly, asking for common methods of calculating emissions, as well as verification and publication of data so that all industries and sectors are subject to the same scale, seems to be a most legitimate request and not a negotiating tool.
Finally, more controversially, and as my colleague mentioned earlier, the shortcomings of the current Clean Development Mechanism system will also need to be addressed.
Dear colleagues, we are all well aware, albeit with regret, that the real negotiating power does not lie with the European Parliament.
But the willingness of many European MPs, including myself, to work and participate in a positive outcome of this conference must be encouraged and not neglected, as we have felt in recent days.
If Europe wants to be strong in international dialogues, the same must apply to all these legislators.
Madam President, the European Union often presents economic partnership agreements as an opportunity for African countries.
Is she therefore despairing because she does not see these agreements being signed quickly?
But the question that concerns us is why these countries are not rushing to sign agreements that are favorable to them.
Clearly, opinions differ on the quality of these agreements, and as long as these differing opinions persist, the ACP countries will be reluctant to sign them.
Would it not be appropriate to go further in dialogue and understanding by listening to the concerns and expectations of ACP countries?
They want to talk about development strategies, while Europe often responds with only market opening.
This is the kind of listening that the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly must impose on itself.
I believe that other European institutions should follow the same approach if we want to build a genuine strategic partnership between Africa and the European Union.
Mr. President, Christians are undoubtedly one of the most persecuted religious groups in the world.

In the Middle East, they are perceived by certain extremist groups as, and I quote, legitimate targets, and the goal is their outright departure from this region, a region that saw the birth of Christianity and in which their historical presence is necessary for a certain balance.
The events at Baghdad Cathedral are merely the culmination of a situation we have been passively observing for far too long.
The European Union, as a global player and trading partner of many countries in this region, must strongly express its indignation at the situation.
Discrimination, in any form, cannot be tolerated.
Democracy will only be victorious in this region when the most fundamental human rights, such as religious freedom, are respected.
My colleagues, we are all concerned by the serious crisis currently taking place in Cte d'Ivoire.

It is evident that the decision of the Constitutional Council of this country to challenge, in violation of the electoral code, the results of the elections officially proclaimed by the Independent Electoral Commission is unanimously condemned by the international community.

The European Union, the UN, the African Union, the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, the KoAs and soon, certainly, the European Parliament are calling for respect for the official proclamation of the.
election results and the installation of the new President of the Republic, as recognized by the Independent Electoral Commission, which, I would remind you, is a body validated by the UN.
All the political groups in the European Parliament expressed their agreement on these essential points in a joint statement.

They also called for preventing any escalation of tension in the country that could lead to civil war, which would be a human, social, and economic disaster for Cte d'Ivoire, and which must obviously be avoided at all costs.

Madam President, I would like to take my turn in thanking our four rapporteurs who have done an outstanding job and added significant value from the European Parliament to the text initially proposed by the Commission.
The citizens' initiative that we in the EPP are preparing to vote for with enthusiasm is a major step forward in the Lisbon Treaty.

Let us make no mistake about it, this instrument can genuinely change the European political landscape, provided it is used with both responsibility and boldness. I repeat, responsibility and boldness.
It can help bring European citizens directly into the European political debate.

It can help to foster a European public opinion, that is to say, men and women who are citizens of Europe, who debate together, who take a stand together, and who come together on truly European issues.
But do not disappoint our fellow citizens.
Let us urge our member states to take the necessary enforcement measures quickly. Let us not disappoint our fellow citizens, for this is about strengthening European democracy.
Mr President, I would like, in turn, like several of our colleagues, to address the issue of the persecution of Christians throughout the world, particularly Eastern Christians.
It is unnecessary to recall the horrific acts perpetrated recently.
I would like to reiterate that, in the same way as defending Christians in the East, as everywhere in the world, advocating for religious freedom, diversity of

The crux is to advocate for freedom, democracy, and human rights, which are core values of the European project and which are, of course, universal values, at least that is what we are all convinced of here.
It is truly time now, beyond indignation, emotion, and solemn condemnations, of course, it is truly time now to turn words into actions.
I urgently call on the European Union authorities, the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, as well as all our leaders, the foreign ministers.
Implement specific measures to establish a precise, concrete action plan to make respect for religious diversity and the fight against all forms of religious persecution a priority. Thank you.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam High Representative, we all agree that the situation in the Sahel region has significantly deteriorated.
And allowing a lawless zone to establish itself in European ports is a danger that we must fight against firmly and without delay.
Extremist groups are multiplying and threatening the lives of civilians.
For my part, I deplore the loss of life and the taking of hostages and am concerned for the European nationals on the ground.
Until now, Morocco has been a bulwark against all kinds of trafficking coming from the Sahel.
Or now, drug, arms, and human traffickers bypass Morocco by going through Mauritania towards the Canary Islands in the direction of the European Union.
It seems to me that it is the responsibility of the European Union to take action to help these states put an end to these threats.
Europe's security is at stake on our territory, but also in its immediate neighborhood.
It is time for us to act and I call on the Commission and the Council to implement an action plan to help restore security in the Sahel.
That has been said, but I join in the expressions of sympathy and support that have already been made towards the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples.
It represents a symbol of hope for all freedom fighters.
A thought also for the victims.

I would now like to say that the European Union, which, as has been mentioned, has been noted for its lack of reaction, must indeed stand by the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples to help them successfully open their countries up to reform and establish democracy.

The European Union has decided to support the Tunisian leaders in order to initiate a peaceful transition, prepare the organization of the upcoming elections to gain freedom and allow the Tunisian people to find prosperity, development and social peace, an economy that will enable the youth to find employment.

In conclusion, I would say that the Union for the Mediterranean faces a significant challenge because the Jasmine Revolution has triggered a wave of change across all the states of the Maghreb, the Near East, and the Middle East.
It must implement a strong strategy towards these countries.
But beware, faced with this legitimate democratic movement, Europe must find a balance between non-interference in internal affairs, support for the legitimate aspirations of peoples, and stability.
Commissioner, my colleagues have reiterated this point time and time again.
At a time when Europe is considering a common strategy for its supply of raw materials, particularly rare earths, we cannot overlook the immense potential of intelligently valorizing our waste.

Strengthening European standards to improve the functioning of collection systems, addressing problems of leakage or illegal export, and increasing our collection targets must also be at the core of this legislation.
Let us not forget the main actor in the success or failure of this regulation, the consumer.
Empowering citizens is crucial if we want to implement effective legislation,
And to achieve this, my dear Carolines, the eco-contribution, among other systems, has proven to be a most relevant tool.

Producers of electronic and electrical equipment must, of course, become more involved in the collection and recycling system, but citizens cannot be absolved of responsibility for the waste they produce.
Our citizens must be active participants, not passive observers, in European environmental policy.

Madam President, Mr President, Commissioner, I would first like to share the comment that Mrs McGuinness just made about the fact that there is an essential link between the food issue and the agricultural issue.
The issue that concerns us is the rise in food prices and the consequences this can have for a number of populations around the world, but also in Europe.
I would first like to try to share an observation.
The trend of rising agricultural prices and raw materials is a long-term trend for me, and it will last for three essential reasons: the demographic evolution of the world and the increase

the world's population. The second element is that we have entered a period of problematic climate variability due to global warming, whether it be drought or flooding. The third point is that the world is also developing.
With new emerging countries, consumption levels are increasing.
The tension in agricultural markets and agricultural raw materials is a significant trend.
It is exacerbated by price volatility, and price volatility is a consequence of the financialization of the global economy.
This is the issue that must also be addressed if we want to resolve both the agricultural and food issues.

To achieve this, what the Commissioner said is important. There are two elements: yes, we need transparency on stocks, but we also need a public policy on stocks in Europe and stock management on a global scale, particularly at the UN level.

Second point, there must be regulation of financial markets and financial speculation, particularly by refusing to allow speculative volume to have no connection with the physical quantities that are traded on the markets.

We cannot accept that, on the food issue, speculators come to speculate without taking into account the consequences this may have, since it is about the food of the world and humanity. I conclude by saying
This leads me to two major consequences: we need a strong European policy and we strategically reaffirm Europe's commitment to being a global player in food and agriculture.

Secondly, we need to change our development policy so that, on a global scale and as a European player, we invest again in agriculture, because we will need all forms of agriculture to feed the world.
Madam President, Commissioner, just like in 2008, the price of agricultural raw materials is rising on the global markets?
We are only at three percent of the level of two thousand eight.
the decline in production in certain traditional exporting areas due to climate change, the diversion of grain to agrofuel production, and speculation
The financial policies that exacerbate the upward effects are responsible for this situation, as shown by reports from the IMF and the French authorities, and as the Commission also states.
The consequences of this new food crisis are severely affecting the 1.2 billion people worldwide who live on less than $1 a day.
Since October, an additional forty-four million people have joined those who were already below the poverty line.
Two days before the G20 meeting, what is Europe waiting for to take similar measures to those voted on in the United States?
Since January 13, 2011, the US administration has required the limitation and transparency of positions taken by financial funds in agricultural commodity markets.
This breakthrough is a first step in countering the appetites of speculators.
The impact is also dramatic for European breeders.
They are no longer able to feed their animals.
Hundreds of farms are going bankrupt.
Five years ago, wheat was worth 100 euros per tonne. Today, it is trading at nearly 300 euros.
The situation has therefore completely changed.
The Commission demands that farmers adapt to market signals. It would be wise today to follow its own advice.
Faced with this crisis, the European Union cannot afford to find solutions in 2014.
We must address the crisis, and I propose three concrete actions.
First, the creation of stocks in grain-producing countries to make them available to farmers at subsidized prices immediately.
Secondly, the indexation of meat prices paid to farmers to the evolution of the cost of cattle feed.
Thirdly, for 2011, a mechanism to transfer a portion of the aid intended for cereal support to animal production. Thank you.
Mr President, are we in Europe ready to face a pandemic?
The answer is yes, but there's a but.
The H1N1 flu episode of 2009-2010 showed us that each Member State reacted on its own, without much coherence or even solidarity.

As the shadow rapporteur on this issue, I believe that these observations needed to be made, but above all, we must go further and be constructive and concrete for our citizens. It must be said, and this is what seems to me to be most damaging, that we have probably lost some confidence in public health messages.

Mrs. Rivasi's report, which will be voted on tomorrow, takes into account her fundamental priorities, which include, among other things, the systematic strengthening of cooperation between Member States, better coordination with the
European health institutions, clarification of the roles of European health risk management structures, an evaluation of vaccination and communication strategies implemented in the Member States.
It is therefore a good report. I congratulate the rapporteur. But of course, it must not remain a dead letter.
It is the responsibility of our member states, which retain the majority of the relevant powers. It is therefore a genuine responsibility to be taken towards our citizens.
Mr President, it is my turn to express my profound emotion following the cowardly assassination last March of the Pakistani minister responsible for Christian religious minorities, Mr Batti.
This terrorist assassination follows many others of courageous, tolerant Pakistanis who are lovers of human rights and defenders of human and women's rights, I must say.

Once again, we urge the Pakistani government to shed full light on this cowardly assassination and to effectively, truly effectively, ensure the protection of those threatened by fanatical religious extremists.
I am thinking, of course, above all, but not exclusively, of Mrs. Chery Raymond.
I also wanted, once again, to strongly urge all the relevant institutions of the European Union to include in the negotiations aimed at
prepare future cooperation agreements, including the cooperation agreement between the EU and Pakistan, with a clause on respect for religious freedom and human rights.
Mr President, for your information, during the crisis and the explosion of the housing bubble and credit, the Irish state had to intervene to support the banks.

Ireland's public deficit, the cumulative budget balance of central and local government administrations, and particularly social security, is estimated at thirty-two percent of the gross domestic product in 2010.

If the Irish government, which is having difficulty refinancing itself on the markets, wishes to access loans from the mechanism and the European Financial Stability Fund, it will have to meet obligations for social and fiscal changes, even though these areas fall under the principle of subsidiarity.
In our view, this is not contradictory.
As a doctor, I would say that in the case of fever, it is useless to prescribe antipyretics blindly without trying to treat the cause.
If these funds are allocated, it is up to this state to clean up its finances in order to cover its excessive deficit and correct its previous mistakes.
This austerity plan is expected to improve the GDP by ten percent over the next four years.

Just as a private individual, without interfering in their private life and management, will make their personal loan conditional on a guarantee of solvency, so too can the European Union lend to Ireland on the basis of consolidated solvency.
without interfering in its private management, the bank will encourage the individual to negotiate, for example, a salary increase or to borrow elsewhere.

Thus, while respecting subsidiarity, the European Union, based on a memorandum established with the IMF, considers that this solvency requires a reduction in the minimum legal wage and an adjustment of pensions, without exempting itself from fiscal measures.
It is up to Ireland to decide whether or not to implement these measures.

This is not an open door to European Union interference in areas of subsidiarity, which would, for example, dangerously impose a European minimum wage level, but a protection of the stability of the eurozone through a process of mutual guarantee.

It is of course important to help Ireland, as well as other countries in difficulty, which also protects us, but not at any price, especially not at the price of having a state that is unable to repay its debts in the long term, thereby weakening its citizens and those of the entire European Union.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the eruption of the Icelandic volcano last April, as many of us have said earlier, provided a painful illustration of the fragmentation and inefficiency of European airspace.
Each one of us in this chamber has been directly affected.
five million of our fellow citizens found themselves stranded without any real alternative transport solutions.
And a year after this exceptional event, new European measures are still pending.

A first crisis exercise, as you mentioned, Commissioner, related to volcanic ash is indeed planned for April 13 and 14, under the coordination of Eurocontrol and IATA, but it is essential that the ESA takes on real leadership for the coordination of safety measures at the European level.
It is certain that the information provided by the London and Toulouse waves must be refined using more modern technological means.
However, as we saw last April, this data can be contradictory and can lead each Member State to make decisions about closing their airspace that are less motivated by information than by emotion.
In this context, the role of the ESA is essential in providing a harmonized interpretation of this data, as well as ensuring the centralization and proper dissemination of information.
Beyond VAC information, AISAA must establish a mechanism for collecting available data by closely involving member states, airlines, and their pilots.
This centralization of information and coordination of all stakeholders involved will prevent the chaos and inconsistencies we witnessed last year.
I therefore expect the Commission, together with the ESA, to quickly present concrete proposals that will fully integrate into the implementation of the Single European Sky.
Dear colleagues, this tax is important.
This is not a revolution. We cannot say that everything was bad before and everything is perfect now.
But, nonetheless, it presents a number of major advances at this provisional stage of our work.
In my opinion, the main issues relate to better regulation of distance selling, particularly on the internet. And that is chapter 3, because we need to strengthen consumer rights in this area.
E-commerce is very useful, it broadens the consumer's choice, it allows them to get the lowest prices and it also allows small and medium-sized enterprises and artisans to find new outlets.
To make progress in this area, it had to be done in a truly European way, that is to say, on a few very targeted points, implementing a complete harmonisation of everyone's rights and duties.
In practical terms, an Italian customer buying from a Belgian or German site needed to know that they would now benefit from the same rights and the same protection.
This is what this directive will make possible.
This means that the withdrawal period will be extended to fourteen days throughout the Union.
This means that he will immediately know the total amount he will have to pay, without worrying about any unpleasant surprises later on.
This means that, thanks to the double-click, he will correctly check his order.
Of course, all of this will disrupt certain habits.
In many details, there are subtleties in national law that everyone is convinced are fundamental, even though sometimes they are not even found in neighboring countries.
But living together in Europe means learning to modify one's habits a little in the service of the community and general interest.
Let's be clear: this text still needs to be improved, and we will have to do so in the coming weeks with the Council and the Commission.
I appreciated the openings that have just been made in this regard.
But we have already done substantial work, thanks to our rapporteur Andr Ashchoab, whom I warmly thank.
But the real fruit of this work is above all the fact that the amendments will be voted on tomorrow by all the political groups.
Consumer confidence in the EU's internal market is very fragile.
This political unanimity was necessary to preserve it and to hope to strengthen it.
At point number seven after the first paragraph, a first indent guarantees respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, in particular the
freedom of speech and assembly, and the right to demonstrate peacefully, and to listen to and take into account the legitimate demands of demonstrators and ensure their safety.
Madam President, my dear colleagues, Commissioner, the open agreement between Europe and the United States is a step forward, but it is only a preliminary step that places Europe before a dilemma.
The Transport Committee and the Commission itself have pointed this out.
either we accept an agreement that disadvantages European companies, or we suspend the agreement and risk losing the benefits gained since 2008.
Let me draw a parallel with the private and professional pilot licenses, a text that will be discussed before summer, because the pilots I am part of are faced with a dilemma.
the European Aviation Safety Agency, wishing to harmonize licenses across European territory, will do so at the expense of the eighty-four thousand general aviation pilots
Directly concerned, some holding only one American license, and to the detriment of companies and jobs linked to this activity.
I would like to draw your attention to this project, which has no security basis.
There are 31 times fewer accidents among American license holders.

The objectives of the basic regulatory text 216 make it possible to provide for the recognition and equivalence of licenses for which there is no point in waiting for hypothetical agreements that were rejected in 2014.
So, I propose a very open sky agreement and even invite you to accompany me when I come to Parliament, flying myself to demonstrate that an American pilot's license is perfectly safe.
Madam President, at this stage of our debate, I will inevitably be led to repeat or support certain things that have been said previously.

Mr President, I would firstly like to congratulate all the rapporteurs on their enormous work on this dossier and I also welcome the Council's presence for this debate.
The seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg is a matter of European identity and is not just a matter of economics.

since we want to save money, I propose other things, for example, eliminating the Friday per diem for our colleagues, as well as eliminating the per diems for journalists.
