Madam President, I address the Commission and my colleagues, and I welcome the presence of the Council.
The question that arises today stems from the management of the Schengen area in 2011.

This is no longer the space of the five member states of the eighties; on the contrary, it is a space that has continually expanded in recent years and now includes twenty-five states, three of which are not members of the European Union.
Like all European policies, Schengen cooperation must therefore adapt to the reality it now covers, which is no longer the same as it was ten years ago.

This is the context in which the proposals of the Italian and French governments and the pragmatic and necessary responses provided today by the Commission in its communication on immigration should be read.
Mutual trust between the Schengen states is indeed the cornerstone of Schengen cooperation.
But this trust is based on mutual obligations.
If one of the parties fails to meet its obligations and creates air leaks, the entire system becomes faulty.
It should therefore be possible for other states to respond to this failure by re-establishing temporary and strictly controlled border checks.
In doing so, these failing states will be clearly invited to better control their external borders.

Moreover, as presented by the Commission, these measures would fully respect the Schengen spirit, insofar as these controls would be reintroduced as a last resort and the decision would be made at the European level and not through intergovernmental cooperation.
Such measures will be intrinsically linked to all measures envisaged in the long term with a view to a common migration policy.
It is particularly essential to strengthen Frontex and provide more solidarity to support the states located at the external borders.
The situation in the Mediterranean in recent years has only highlighted a shortcoming of the Schengen Agreement.
In two minutes, Madam President, in a few weeks, migrants from the countries bordering the Mediterranean have represented a significant percentage of annual French immigration.
This achievement is not static, but must, on the contrary, evolve.
I hope that this proposal will be quickly adopted in order to ensure better management of our Schengen area and to guarantee the security of our common external borders. Thank you.

we all in this chamber appreciate the impact of this kind of decision on the citizens concerned.

Mr President, in its Europe 2020 strategy, the European Union has set itself the goal of making our economy greener and our transport more modern.
All European institutions have broadly supported this objective, including almost all the Member States and our Parliament.
In this context, it is therefore regrettable that, since 2008, several Member States have worked to strip the new Eurovignette Directive proposal of its content and block this issue.

Today, however, thanks to the tenacity of our rapporteur, and I would like to pay tribute here to Sad El Kadrawi, thanks to his tenacity and that of the shadow rapporteurs in their negotiations with the Council, we finally have a compromise before us.

So, while this text is much less ambitious than the initial proposal, it will, for the first time, put the polluter pays principle into practice and internalize external transport costs such as noise or CO2 emissions.

In order for this Euro vignette not to be merely a tax, but to actually contribute to the improvement of transportation in Europe, the member states are also encouraged to reinvest the collected money in the modernization of transportation modes.
Parliament has also managed to secure concrete developments in the interoperability of toll systems, as well as stronger incentives for the use of cleaner heavy-duty vehicles.

In order to remain consistent with the political objectives set by our institution, I sincerely hope that we will be able to adopt the compromise proposed to us in second reading and thus pave the way for a more sustainable transport policy. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, yes, I agree that, along with liberty and fraternity, there should be equality with the peasants and the countries that have returned, including those returning from the East.

and also towards a discipline that we have sorely missed, a step, I say, that will only show its usefulness in the future.

As the coming weeks are crucial, the challenge today is to rebuild an economic union.
This morning, after three years of work, we voted on a text that is very important for the progress of consumer protection in Europe.
It rightly focuses on online shopping, which may account for 25% of all commerce in Europe in twenty years, which is quite considerable.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, I would first like to commend the efforts of our colleague Carlos Collet on this very difficult issue that required a great deal of technical expertise, hard work, and knowledge of the subject matter.
The control of our common territory and our European borders is one of the most important challenges we face, and technology is more than ever at the service of this challenge.

What some call a digital tsunami is certain to materialize in the coming years.
The SIS, the VIS, and the REDD are all essential instruments today for ensuring the security of our European citizens.
Ensuring good operational management of these databases is therefore a major issue to which it is our responsibility to provide an effective response.

This response is of course very delicate and Carlos Colho had to face numerous legal, institutional, budgetary, political and technical obstacles and he has nevertheless managed to produce a balanced text that satisfies all the parties concerned.
The creation of this agency for networks appears to be the best solution for ensuring the internal security of the member states.
No other existing institution or agency could take charge of the proper management of these information systems today.

It will improve the management of existing information systems, it will offer better synergy between its databases and will also allow for the integration of instruments that will be adopted in the future.
One of the very delicate questions that arose in this matter was the location of the agency: where should it be established?
Estonia and France are the only two countries that have put themselves forward as candidates to host it.
France already hosts the Schengen training system in Strasbourg, where it has been managing its operational and administrative aspects since 1985. As a result, it has full technical control over it.
Following the conclusions of the European Council in December 2003, which gave priority to new members, Estonia also wished to host the headquarters of this future agency.

I believe that the compromise reached is very good. A kind of distribution of emissions, I conclude, Madam President, has taken place by transferring the agency's headquarters to Tallinn, where governance, strategy, and program design tasks will be carried out.
The development and operation of the systems will take place in Strasbourg.
The cost-effectiveness ratio is very well balanced and this co-investment solution in no way undermines the centralized management of IT systems. Madam President,

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, first of all, I would like to thank our colleague Simon Buzitil for the tremendous work he has accomplished.

This report outlines for us an agency with increased resources, more in line with the missions assigned to it.
Recent events have demonstrated the need for closer cooperation between the European Union, the Member States, and the support of a strong agency.
Frontex finally gets the means to fulfill its missions.
By being able to acquire or rent its own equipment and benefit from the services of its own border guards, it becomes more independent and very effective.
New tasks are also assigned to them, such as organizing voluntary returns or processing personal data, so that we can combat cross-border crime while protecting fundamental rights.

This extension of Frontex's field of competence gives us the means to consider and address migration issues through a comprehensive approach, rather than confining ourselves to a mere mechanical border management.
I approve the possibility of exchanging personal data with other European agencies, including Europol.
Finally, the human dimension has taken its rightful place in this report.
A strong recognition of human rights is guaranteed by the proposal to establish an advisory council within the agency.

I can only welcome this comprehensive proposal that takes a step forward towards a sound and responsible management of our external borders, in a context where migratory pressures are particularly strong and continue to grow. Thank you.

more than forty three million Europeans are threatened by food poverty.

Mr President, Commissioner, I will not dwell on the cynicism with which the Arcelor Mittal group announced the closure of some of its facilities in Europe, and in particular in Belgium at Lige, ultimately leading to hundreds of direct job losses and putting several thousand indirect jobs at risk.
As a native of Lige, I share the shock and dismay of the five hundred and twenty-one workers who have been laid off from their family.
But I also think of the severe restructuring carried out by the steel group in France, Germany and Luxembourg.
The reasons cited are always the same: poor prospects for the steel market in Europe, fierce competition from imports from China, Korea.
Russia and Brazil, the reduction in the automotive market, and finally the competitiveness gap, for example between the Lige site and the best factories in Northern Europe.
In addition, despite a challenging 2010, the financial center of the steel group ArcelorMittal Belgium generated a profit of one billion three hundred ninety-four million euros.
He paid zero euros in taxes, which means a tax rate of zero.
This is particularly shocking.
Group management is primarily financial, with a stop-and-go policy implemented across several sites.
In the minds of its leaders, the closure of sites is nothing more than an economic adjustment variable where human issues are of little importance.
This is no longer acceptable.
You spoke, Commissioner, about the rules.
Wouldn't it be time for the Commission to develop a binding code of social responsibility for multinational companies?

It has been six years since our Parliament adopted a report on relocation, the code of conduct for companies, the reimbursement of subsidies, and mandatory consultation between companies, trade unions, and public authorities.
Since then, it must be acknowledged that little concrete progress has been made on these various proposals.
What does the Commission intend to do about this and within what timeframe?
If we want to support the competitiveness of companies and make Europe attractive in terms of economic investment, we also need to adopt a legislative framework.
Europe needs to be strong to cope with relocation and restructuring, and to ensure that another form of capital, human capital, is fully taken into account.
Finally, in the case of the Lige site, I hope it will be able to benefit from the intervention of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support the dismissed workers. Thank you.

without any social ethics that carries out stock market layoffs and delocalizes to reduce costs, increase shareholder profits, and please rating agencies in disregard of social and environmental standards.

Commissioner, we can no longer continue to look separately at the issue of structural funds and the Globalisation Adjustment Fund without
It is well to bear in mind the restructuring strategies of companies that benefit from them without examining the cost-benefit ratio of a policy, I repeat.
Mr President, the European Ombudsman conducts investigations into complaints against the institutions and bodies of the European Union, with brio.

This instrument is both necessary to facilitate the free movement of our businesses and citizens, but it is also a formidable guarantee, especially in the face of the Union's detractors, who all too often say that the European Union is nothing more than a bureaucratic machine without control.
This is clearly nonsensical. Europe is genuinely working on itself, thanks to European mediators, among others.
But let me relay a fact that I deeply regret, in which the Commission is under fire for criticism.
First, there are the figures of sixty-five and the true figure, not twelve, of investigations opened by the Ombudsman concerning the European Commission.

There are also stakeholders. Many companies come to us to express their frustration with a European Commission that remains deaf to their requests, particularly regarding access to documents. The same applies to the issue of transparency in decision-making.
Few people understand it.
And finally, from personal experience, I must admit that I have sometimes been shocked by the reactions of certain European Commission services present in the Committee on Petitions.
As you know, the European Commission provides us with its position on petitions, a position that we always take into account and which is necessary.

But it occasionally happens to see representatives of the European Commission who refuse to answer a Member's questions or who hide behind empty words almost as well as politicians and those addressing citizens to plead their cause.

I therefore wanted to remind you that Europe must have a human face, that behind the administrative problems that the Ombudsman identifies and resolves, there are Europeans who are eager to be heard but are disappointed by

Citizens' behaviors are then negatively marked by their confrontation with the institutions, potentially creating a sense of revolt, incomprehension, and, in the long term, perhaps even Euroscepticism.
I sincerely hope that these criticisms and those of the Ombudsman against the institutions in general are heard. Thank you.
Madam President, professional mobility and growth, professional mobility and competitiveness of our European Union, these are indeed the terms in which today's topic is framed.

The main recommendations of this report are for greater professional mobility, greater simplification and efficiency in the procedures for recognizing professional qualifications, while ensuring patient safety and consumer safety.

who pointed out that the Member States had to recognise the potential of the internal market for boosting growth and job creation and had to act to remove all obstacles to the completion of the internal market.
Similarly, the European Council of October 23rd also set as one of the essential priorities for achieving smart, sustainable growth, I quote:
including the implementation of the twelve priority proposals in the Single Market Act, the twelve proposals made by the Commission, including the recognition of professional qualifications

We can clearly see that it is by increasing professional mobility that we can hope to unleash the growth potential contained in the internal market, our internal market of 500 million inhabitants and 500 million consumers.

Professional mobility must therefore not only ensure, if we strengthen it, modernize it, and improve it, the free movement of our compatriots within this market, but also allow us to acquire, we hope, additional margins of growth.
This is why we have, in particular, I will emphasize a practical recommendation: we PPE have particularly oriented our support towards the implementation of a professional volunteer program.

Certainly, the crisis is economic and financial, but above all, for our fellow citizens, it is a social crisis.

As rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development, I am pleased that the Committee on Fisheries has incorporated the elements contained in our opinion, as it is crucial that the development dimension
should be taken into account in measures to combat illegal fishing at global level, in the name of policy coherence and close links with development policy.
Indeed, the fight against illegal fishing requires comprehensive solutions and enforcement by all states, including developing ones.
However, it is necessary that the technical and financial capacities of the states are also taken into account in the actions to be undertaken.
Indeed, one cannot impose the same constraints without accompanying measures on developed or developing countries.
Small island states, for example, have very limited capacities.
They must therefore be supported in their efforts to combat illegal fishing.
This is why the Union will need to increase the financial envelope for the fisheries sector when it concludes agreements in this area in developing countries.

Furthermore, it is crucial that measures to combat illegal fishing are implemented, as this practice undermines the development of countries by reducing the financial resources that these countries could derive from the fishing industry.
Or, these resources are necessary for developing countries to implement social, economic, and education policies.

Finally, it is important that the European Union promotes, when implementing these measures to combat illegal fishing in developing countries, the involvement of civil society and businesses alongside the beneficiary states.
A holistic approach is necessary to stem the tide of this scourge that is illegal fishing. Thank you.

Commissioner, the personal data protection standards of third countries still differ considerably from European standards.
However, it is our duty to ensure that our minimum European standards of protection, which we rely on, are respected and guaranteed to European citizens.
It is fundamental that personal data be processed fairly and collected for specified and legitimate purposes.
European citizens must be guaranteed the right to access and rectify their personal data, as well as the ability to file a legal complaint in the event of a violation of their rights.
Action must be taken to allow European and international standards to coexist and to resolve a potential legal conflict that could be detrimental to European citizens.
European legislation alone is not enough.
It must articulate and coexist intelligently with international standards, because we can rid ourselves of our duties and commitments to European citizens.
This situation echoes other debates within this chamber.
It reminds us of the relevance of projects such as the establishment of a European programme for monitoring the financing of terrorism.
Such a system would provide us with a tool that has proven effective in the United States, while fully respecting domestic law and, consequently, the protection of European citizens' personal data.
European institutions must continue their commitment in this regard and fully assume their protection standards. Thank you.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to start by rejecting the unfounded claims that between 500 and one million fake biometric passports are circulating in France.
France takes the risk of identity pool fraud very seriously.
It does not take such offences lightly.
At the initiative of its government, identity theft is an offense punishable by one year in prison and a 15 euro fine.
The conditions for issuing identity documents have been simplified, allowing prefectures to free up additional resources to combat this fraud.
Thus, a fraud liaison officer is appointed in each prefecture.
In addition, the security measures and procedures for issuing identity documents have been strengthened.
For example, civil status data provided can be verified between administrative departments as much as possible by dematerialized means in order to limit the risks of falsification.
Some birth certificates are also issued on secure paper.
The same rigor applies to the supporting documents proving the address.
The Ministry of the Interior has embarked on a path towards increased security of proof of address with the insertion of a barcode.

The standard processing of a title application includes authorized consultation of relevant files, comparison of all documents submitted in previous title applications, and possible authentication of supporting documents.

The security of the issuance of documents is further guaranteed by the applicant's dual appearance 1 at the time of application submission and subsequently at the time of document collection, as well as the taking of two sets of fingerprints.
Not to mention the enhanced checks for renewing lost and stolen titles for comparative purposes with the data kept by the prefectures. I'm finished.

Furthermore, France reports to international cooperation bodies, particularly Interpol, and I am almost finished, Mr. President, with the passports issued or lost and stolen so that they are not used for fraudulent purposes.
My dear colleagues, France, like the European Union network, is committed.

Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, it should be noted that our fellow citizens increasingly wish to find and consume locally produced and seasonal food, particularly for health and quality reasons.
We must find ways to enable farmers to respond effectively and quickly to this growing demand.

We must support the establishment of local infrastructures for producers, such as maintaining nearby slaughterhouses that, while ensuring rigorous health control, enable the development of local short supply chains and strengthen direct sales.
Support for local agriculture and direct sales should help producers to market their products and make them known to consumers.
Strengthening these direct relationships will enable farmers to retain a larger share of the added value created on their farms.

Direct sales on the farm should be encouraged and facilitated, and collective actions by farmers who wish to open collective sales points should be supported, allowing a wider range of products to be offered to local consumers.

The European Commission must facilitate the emergence, sustainability, and development of direct-to-consumer delivery sales systems, such as the amAP in France, which enable nearly 3 farmers to supply sixty families.

Finally, Member States must be able to add other criteria, particularly concerning the size of the farm, the volume of production, or the traditional nature of the product, in order to define local agriculture.

Commissioner, the problem of the availability of public consultations in different languages was unfortunately not new to him.
I believe this is a crucial issue, which is why I have not only asked several written questions to the European Commission since 2008, but I have also personally written to Mr Barroso.

Indeed, the Commission must comply with the principle of equal access to information for all European citizens, as the Court of First Instance of the European Communities recalled in its judgment of November 20, 2008.
I was not at all satisfied with the European Commission's response, according to which public consultations do not claim to provide a completely representative picture of all opinions.
According to this response, the Commission takes into account the fact that certain positions and views may be overrepresented to the detriment of others.
That's not an answer.
I am wondering about the criteria that would allow us to measure an overrepresentation of the European population.
If written consultations are not representative because of availability in English only, for example, they miss their goal of consulting European citizens.
Thus, the result gives a misleading indication and should therefore not be used by the European Commission.
If we want to retain secret consultations as a tool underlying the legislative proposals of the European Commission, we must ensure that they are democratic, transparent, and fair for all citizens.
Thus, if the European Commission makes the written request, it must take responsibility and ensure the necessary resources for multilingualism and the translation of questionnaires.

It seemed important to me to point out that when a country that practices unsustainable fishing is to be sanctioned, its level of development must be taken into account.

In fact, in the name of the principle of policy coherence with development objectives, it is crucial, in my opinion, that measures adopted in the field of fisheries do not undermine the development plans and strategies implemented by the European Union in these countries.
Mr Gallagher's draft report takes up this important idea for our development committee by stipulating that measures must not be unjustified or even discriminatory.

I therefore call on the European Commission, when adopting such measures, to respect this principle of policy coherence with development objectives and to take due account of the level of development and vulnerability of the countries concerned. Thank you.
The third reform of the common fisheries policy must not once again be carried out against the interests of fishermen.

No, not all fishermen are these plunderers of the sea, solely responsible for the poor health of stocks, as claimed by environmental organizations and the European Commission, which lump all categories of fishing together.

It goes without saying that fish stocks must be preserved, but our fishermen must also be able to make a living from their activities, and the economic fabric, dynamism, and cultural identity of our coastal regions must be preserved.
Or, the main measures of the European executive once again aim to reduce the number of fishermen in order to achieve the mythical maximum sustainable yield.
I would like to remind you that the French fleet has decreased by more than fifty since 1980.

The Commission proposes, in particular, the introduction of individual transferable quotas, a guarantee of industrialization and concentration in the sector, as well as a total ban on discards, which professionals consider unrealistic.
This reform project is probably suitable for the industrial fleet, but in the state, it would mean the programmed death of what remains of local and artisanal fishing.

Having achieved this, we must ask ourselves how we can improve our aid, making it more consistent with our trade policy, our agricultural policy, and our foreign policy.
The future of European development policy must be based on specific, measurable commitments, with a short- and medium-term timetable.
The economic crisis, climate change, the power of emerging countries and land grabbing force us to define new priorities to ensure food security, access to energy resources and access to healthcare.

2015 will also be an opportunity to better take into account the geostrategic evolution of recent years, as the emerging countries of today were still developing countries not long ago.
